title: About
text: My name is Rohan, this is my data science portfolio website. I am passionate and meticulous Data Analyst who is passionate about transforming intricate data sets into actionable information. Experienced in utilizing statistical analysis and visualization tools to facilitate decision-making based on data-driven insights. Demonstrated proficiency in SQL and Python, as well as data visualization tools like Tableau.

title: Analyzing Customer Purchase Behavior: A Retail Exploration
text:
Welcome to a journey through the world of data analysis! In this blog post, we’ll unravel insights from customer purchase behavior in the retail industry using R. Understanding customer behavior is crucial for businesses, and we’ll leverage R to gain valuable insights from our data.


Imagine you have a dataset containing information about customer purchases at a retail store. Our goal is to explore patterns and trends in customer behavior. Can we identify factors that influence purchase decisions, such as the time of day or specific products?



Before we dive into the code, let’s take a preliminary look at our dataset and understand its characteristics.


Code
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)



Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union


Code
# Generate a synthetic retail dataset for illustration purposes
set.seed(456)
customer_data <- tibble(
  customer_id = 1:200,
  purchase_amount = rnorm(200, mean = 50, sd = 20),
  time_of_day = sample(c("morning", "afternoon", "evening"), 200, replace = TRUE)
)

# Display the first few rows of the dataset
head(customer_data)


# A tibble: 6 × 3
  customer_id purchase_amount time_of_day
        <int>           <dbl> <chr>      
1           1            23.1 evening    
2           2            62.4 morning    
3           3            66.0 afternoon  
4           4            22.2 evening    
5           5            35.7 afternoon  
6           6            43.5 evening    


Code
# Visualize the distribution of purchase amounts
ggplot(customer_data, aes(x = purchase_amount)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 10, fill = "skyblue", color = "black") +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Purchase Amounts", x = "Purchase Amount", y = "Frequency")





Code
# Explore the relationship between time of day and purchase amount
ggplot(customer_data, aes(x = time_of_day, y = purchase_amount)) +
  geom_boxplot(fill = "lightgreen", color = "black") +
  labs(title = "Purchase Amounts by Time of Day", x = "Time of Day", y = "Purchase Amount")

title: Exploring Linear Regression in R: A Predictive Modeling Adventure
text:
Welcome to another exciting data science journey! In this blog post, we’ll delve into the fascinating world of Linear Regression using R. Linear Regression is a powerful statistical method for modeling the relationship between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables. Our objective is to predict outcomes and gain insights from our data.


Imagine you have a dataset containing information about student performance. We are curious to explore whether there’s a relationship between the number of hours a student studies and their exam scores. Can we use Linear Regression to predict scores based on study hours?



Before we jump into the code, let’s take a peek at our dataset and explore its characteristics.


Code
# Load necessary libraries
library(ggplot2)

# Generate a synthetic dataset for illustration purposes
set.seed(123)
study_hours <- rnorm(100, mean = 25, sd = 5)
exam_scores <- 50 + 3 * study_hours + rnorm(100, mean = 0, sd = 10)
study_data <- data.frame(study_hours, exam_scores)

# Display the first few rows of the dataset
head(study_data)


  study_hours exam_scores
1    22.19762    109.4888
2    23.84911    124.1162
3    32.79354    145.9137
4    25.35254    122.5822
5    25.64644    117.4231
6    33.57532    150.2757


Code
# Visualize the relationship between study hours and exam scores
ggplot(study_data, aes(x = study_hours, y = exam_scores)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Relationship Between Study Hours and Exam Scores", x = "Study Hours", y = "Exam Scores")





Code
# Build the Linear Regression model
linear_model <- lm(exam_scores ~ study_hours, data = study_data)

# Display the summary of the Linear Regression model
summary(linear_model)



Call:
lm(formula = exam_scores ~ study_hours, data = study_data)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-19.073  -6.835  -0.875   5.806  32.904 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)  51.5956     5.5265   9.336 3.34e-15 ***
study_hours   2.8951     0.2138  13.544  < 2e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 9.707 on 98 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.6518,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.6482 
F-statistic: 183.4 on 1 and 98 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


Code
# Create a scatter plot with the regression line
ggplot(study_data, aes(x = study_hours, y = exam_scores)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "red") +
  labs(title = "Linear Regression: Study Hours vs Exam Scores", x = "Study Hours", y = "Exam Scores")


`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'
